Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation2: A noise complaint is reported due to a late-night party disturbing neighbors
Story:
The night before our family holiday, I was sitting in my living room, phone in hand, ready to call my daughter and confirm the plans for tomorrow. It’s tradition—every year, I make sure to check in, remind everyone how much I’m looking forward to seeing them, and help smooth over any last-minute details. Just as I was about to dial, my police radio crackled to life. There was a noise complaint on Maple Street—a late-night party, neighbors upset, and I was the closest officer on duty.

I hesitated, feeling the weight of both uniforms I wore. As a grandfather, I knew how much my family counted on me to keep us connected, especially during the holidays. But as a police officer, I was expected to respond immediately, to keep the peace and enforce the law, no matter the hour or my personal plans. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the warmth of my family and the duty I’d sworn to uphold. I stared at the phone, then at my badge, caught in the silent struggle between who I am to my family and who I am to my community.
